items.synopsis: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vows to "change the Middle East" while Hamas threatens to broadcast the execution of captives in return for every Israeli bombing of a civilian house without warning.

title.children: Netanyahu vows to 'change the Middle East' in show of force against Hamas as Hezbollah fires rockets from Lebanon

image.altText: An explosion is seen amongst tightly packed buildings at night time

items.synopsis: Israel has drafted a record 300,000 reservists in its response to a multi-front Hamas attack from Gaza and is "going on the offensive," its chief military spokesperson says.

title.children: Hamas warns it will kill hostages every time Israel strikes as Netanyahu says offensive has 'only started'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Ashleigh Barraclough Shuli Shem Tov says her 20-year-old son, Omer, was taken hostage at the Supernova music festival near Gaza on Saturday and remains missing. Ms Shem Tov, who live in, who lives in Herzliya, Israel, said when the Hamas attack on the festival started, Omer contacted the family and said he and his friends would try to leave. The family got him to share his live location so they could monitor his movements. "We saw the car was going not the right way," Ms Shem Tov told ABC Radio Melbourne. "He was going in the direction to Gaza. "We are shouting to ourselves, 'no no don't go inside'." Ms Shem Tov said she and the family tried to call him and got no answer. But his pin on the map kept moving. "We saw that he was inside Gaza," she said. That evening, she received a video that terrified her. "One of his friends sent us a Telegram video and we saw Omer on a car, handcuffed," she said. "From Saturday morning, I'm in hell. "I cannot do anything for my son, I don't know where he is, I don't know what they're doing to him." She said she had been in contact with the Israeli government, who told her they would do everything to bring him back.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'I'm in hell': Israeli mother fears for son after seeing video of him handcuffed to a car

children.content: Reporting by Ashleigh Barraclough
Shuli Shem Tov says her 20-year-old son, Omer, was taken hostage at the Supernova music festival near Gaza on Saturday and remains missing.
Ms Shem Tov, who live in , who lives in Herzliya, Israel, said when the Hamas attack on the festival started, Omer contacted the family and said he and his friends would try to leave.
The family got him to share his live location so they could monitor his movements.
"We saw the car was going not the right way," Ms Shem Tov told ABC Radio Melbourne.
"He was going in the direction to Gaza.
"We are shouting to ourselves, 'no no don't go inside'."
Ms Shem Tov said she and the family tried to call him and got no answer. But his pin on the map kept moving.
"We saw that he was inside Gaza," she said.
That evening, she received a video that terrified her.
"One of his friends sent us a Telegram video and we saw Omer on a car, handcuffed," she said.
"From Saturday morning, I'm in hell.
"I cannot do anything for my son, I don't know where he is, I don't know what they're doing to him."
She said she had been in contact with the Israeli government, who told her they would do everything to bring him back.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In response to questions about the rally at the Opera House last night, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said "there is nothing to celebrate". "I understand that the Middle East is a complex issue and I, for a long time, have supported the right of Israelis and Palestinians to live in peace and security and to support a resolution long-term of this conflict," he said. "But the actions that we saw on the weekend,they are to be unequivocally condemned. "There is no place for the targeting of innocent civilians." He says he believes it has shocked the world for very good reasons and that is why the world is united in condemnation. In response to Labor Minister Bill Shorten calling the protest anti-Semitic Mr Albanese said that he did not see the demonstration and would use his own language. "But, there has been a rise in anti-Semitism in recent times in Australia," he said. "I've been shocked by some of it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM understands it's a complex issue but says there's 'nothing to celebrate'

mediaThumbnail.caption: Anthony Albanese says he's been shocked recently by instances of anti-Semitism.

children.content: In response to questions about the rally at the Opera House last night,
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
said "there is nothing to celebrate".

"I understand that the Middle East is a complex issue and I, for a long time, have supported the right of Israelis and Palestinians to live in peace and security and to support a resolution long-term of this conflict," he said.
"But the actions that we saw on the weekend,they are to be unequivocally condemned.
"There is no place for the targeting of innocent civilians."
He says he believes it has shocked the world for very good reasons and that is why the world is united in condemnation.
In response to Labor Minister Bill Shorten calling the protest anti-Semitic Mr Albanese said that he did not see the demonstration and would use his own language.
"But, there has been a rise in anti-Semitism in recent times in Australia," he said.
"I've been shocked by some of it."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Nicholas McElroy A former Queensland resident caught up in the conflict in the Middle East says authorities have told him there are no plans to get Australians out of Israel. Keanu Vicente lives in Israel but says he fled from Tel Aviv to Nazareth in the north of the country to avoid the shelling. "I was on the phone to the emergency Australian consular assistance today just asking them for any updates, at the time I called they told me they didn't have any plans for repatriation flights," he says. "The last 12 hours today, it's just been very tense with a lot of bad news pouring in from down south. "A lot of our friends and family lost a lot of people." He says he hid in bomb shelters in Tel Aviv on the day bombing broke out. "We woke up to the bombs and were hiding in the bomb shelters all day there," Mr Vicente says. He says many friends have been called into Israel's reserve forces in response to the conflict. "So that brings about a new sense of worry," he says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian says it's 'tense' in Israel as friends are called up as reservists

children.content: Keanu Vincente with his boyfriend Nadav.
(Supplied)
Reporting by Nicholas McElroy
A former Queensland resident caught up in the conflict in the Middle East says authorities have told him there are no plans to get Australians out of Israel.
Keanu Vicente
lives in Israel but says he fled from Tel Aviv to Nazareth in the north of the country to avoid the shelling.

"I was on the phone to the emergency Australian consular assistance today just asking them for any updates, at the time I called they told me they didn't have any plans for repatriation flights," he says.
"The last 12 hours today, it's just been very tense with a lot of bad news pouring in from down south.
"A lot of our friends and family lost a lot of people."
He says he hid in bomb shelters in Tel Aviv on the day bombing broke out.
"We woke up to the bombs and were hiding in the bomb shelters all day there," Mr Vicente says.
He says many friends have been called into Israel's reserve forces in response to the conflict.
"So that brings about a new sense of worry," he says.

title.children: Collingwood captain backs Yes vote, AEC apologises after wheelchair users unable to enter early voting booth

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Tahnee Jash and Marty Smiley Yesterday, young voters arrived at Sydney TAFE’s pre-polling centre to cast their ballot in the first referendum in 24 years. Campaigners outside told us that some voters were unsure about their choice while others walked in with a clear decision in mind. Voters and campaigners alike said finding accurate information wasn't easy and misinformation and disinformation was visible on social media platforms. So, we asked a few young voters about their choice and how they arrived at their decision: Max, Electrician apprentice "I voted 'no'. I've heard so many things and apparently, it's going to divide the country," he said. Max says amongst his friends who are Indigenous, their views on the referendum are split. "A lot of them have said 'no' but I've also got others that said 'yes'," he said. Not knowing a lot about it, I'm just going to stay out of it and vote 'no'." Laila, UTS student "I'm going to vote 'yes'. I feel like we got a lot of information, some of it false, some of it true," she said. Laila says before the referendum, she assumed First Nations people already had a voice on matters that impacted them. "It's just about giving everyone a chance to have their say in a country that is more rightfully theirs, than ours anyway," she said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Yes and No early voters in Sydney's centre

children.content: Reporting by Tahnee Jash and Marty Smiley
Yesterday, young voters arrived at Sydney TAFE’s pre-polling centre to cast their ballot in the first referendum in 24 years.
Campaigners outside told us that some voters were unsure about their choice while others walked in with a clear decision in mind.
Voters and campaigners alike said finding accurate information wasn't easy and misinformation and disinformation was visible on social media platforms.
So, we asked a few young voters about their choice and how they arrived at their decision:
Max, Electrician apprentice
Max voted no in the Voice to Parliament referendum
(ABC News: Marty Smiley)
"I voted 'no'. I've heard so many things and apparently, it's going to divide the country," he said.
Max says amongst his friends who are Indigenous, their views on the referendum are split.
"A lot of them have said 'no' but I've also got others that said 'yes'," he said.
Not knowing a lot about it, I'm just going to stay out of it and vote 'no'."
Laila, UTS student
Laila voted Yes in the Voice to Parliament referendum
(ABC News: Marty Smiley)
"I'm going to vote 'yes'. I feel like we got a lot of information, some of it false, some of it true," she said.
Laila says before the referendum, she assumed First Nations people already had a voice on matters that impacted them.
"It's just about giving everyone a chance to have their say in a country that is more rightfully theirs, than ours anyway," she said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you need to vote via post in the referendum and haven't put in an application yet you need to get cracking! Postal vote applications close at 6pm local time tomorrow. The easiest way to put in an application is to do it online at the AEC website. In order for your postal vote to be counted, the AEC must receive your vote by the 13th day after referendum voting day — that will be October 27. But you need to complete your postal vote on or before voting day. Read more below about how to vote via post and who's eligible.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: When do postal vote applications close?

featuredLink.title: Postal vote applications for the Voice referendum close tomorrow. Here's who is eligible and how to apply

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Kimberley Price Collingwood Captain Darcy Moore says he will be voting Yes in this weekend's Voice to Parliament referendum. It follows fellow sports star, Panthers NRL Premiership hero Nathan Cleary also announcing his support for a First Nations Voice to Parliament. A week after winning the AFL Premiership, Darcy Moore told RN Breakfast host Patricia Karvelas that despite what some people thought, sport and politics could mix. "I'll be voting yes. To me, I feel like it's an intuitive next step and seems to be an important and practical way to help Indigenous Australians," he said. "There are certainly people out there that want you to shut up and play sport, but we've seen all around the country, like with Nathan Cleary, athletes are human beings and citizens of the country too, so they can exercise their right and say what they want to say and they can do it in a really healthy way. "The argument around division … to my mind there is already advisory bodies for Indigenous Australians that have come and gone as governments have changed. The mechanism has kind of already existed anyway, so by making it sort of permanent in the constitution, it's just locking it in. So in that way it's not anything new." Listen to the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Collingwood captain Darcy Moore backs Yes vote on RN

featuredLink.title: 'I'll be voting Yes': Collingwood captain Darcy Moore backs the Voice - ABC listen

children.content: Darcy Moore celebrating Collingwood's win at the 2023 AFL grand final.
(Getty Images: Jonathan DiMaggio)
Reporting by Kimberley Price
Collingwood Captain Darcy Moore
says he will be voting Yes in this weekend's Voice to Parliament referendum.
It follows fellow sports star,
Panthers NRL Premiership hero Nathan Cleary
also announcing his support for a First Nations Voice to Parliament.
A week after winning the AFL Premiership, Darcy Moore told
RN Breakfast host Patricia Karvelas
that despite what some people thought, sport and politics could mix.
"I'll be voting yes. To me, I feel like it's an intuitive next step and seems to be an important and practical way to help Indigenous Australians," he said.

"There are certainly people out there that want you to shut up and play sport, but we've seen all around the country, like with Nathan Cleary, athletes are human beings and citizens of the country too, so they can exercise their right and say what they want to say and they can do it in a really healthy way.

"The argument around division … to my mind there is already advisory bodies for Indigenous Australians that have come and gone as governments have changed. The mechanism has kind of already existed anyway, so by making it sort of permanent in the constitution, it's just locking it in. So in that way it's not anything new."
Listen to the full interview below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hello, Emily Stewart taking over the blog now. We've got two consumer sentiment surveys out today. The first one is the ANZ-Roy Morgan Consumer Confidence index, which found confidence was up 1.9pts to 80.1 this week. This marks the highest level since February, after the Reserve Bank left official interest rates unchanged for the fourth straight month. Confidence about personal finances has been key to the recent upwards trend, says ANZ Senior Economist Adelaide Timbrell. "One less encouraging reason 'current finances' confidence is likely trending up may be because the question asks participants to compare their current finances to a year ago, and inflation and interest rates were already a central issue for households in late 2022." Looking around the states, consumer confidence was up in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland but slightly down in Western Australia and South Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumers feeling more confident

children.content: Hello,
Emily Stewart taking over the blog now.
We've got two consumer sentiment surveys out today.
The first one is the ANZ-Roy Morgan Consumer Confidence index, which found
confidence was up 1.9pts to 80.1 this week
This marks
the highest level since February
, after the Reserve Bank left
official interest rates unchanged for the fourth straight month
Confidence about personal finances has been key to the recent upwards trend, says ANZ Senior Economist Adelaide Timbrell.

"One less encouraging reason 'current finances' confidence is likely trending up may be because the question asks participants to compare their current finances to a year ago, and inflation and interest rates were already a central issue for households in late 2022."
Looking around the states, consumer confidence was up in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland but slightly down in Western Australia and South Australia.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Origin Energy shares surged 5.5% in value this morning following news that the ACCC has granted authorisation, with conditions, for the proposed $15.35 billion acquisition of the energy giant by Brookfield and MidOcean. It was the highest share price the stock has seen since August 2018 (it's since pulled back slightly, and is currently trading around 4.7% higher). As Reuters reports, the deal will require shareholder approval by 75% of votes cast at a scheme meeting. Australian Super, the largest investor, raised its stake to 14% last month and called the shares undervalued.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Origin Energy share price surges 5.5%

of the energy giant by

It was the highest share price the stock has seen since August 2018 (it's since pulled back slightly, and is currently trading around 4.7% higher).
As Reuters reports, the deal will require shareholder approval by 75% of votes cast at a scheme meeting.
Australian Super
, the largest investor,
raised its stake to 14% last month
and called the shares undervalued.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: That's according to Senator Bridget McKenzie, who chaired the Senate committee that probed the federal government's much-discussed decision to reject Qatar Airways' bid for extra flights. Yesterday the committee released its final report, making 10 recommendations — including that th e committee receive evidence from witnesses who weren't available to attend previous public hearings, specifically naming former Qantas boss Alan Joyce. Senator McKenzie was on News Breakfast this morning discussing the report, and said Mr Joyce will be required to give evidence to get to the bottom of the federal government's decision to block the extra Qatar flights. "We know that [Transport Minister Catherine King] was of a mind to approve that negotiating mandate [with Qatar Airways] in January … but then suddenly it goes quiet. She doesn't approve it, and for six months, that sits on her desk ," Senator McKenzie said. "A week after the prime minister agrees to launch the Yes campaign with Alan Joyce in August, one week after that diary entry was made, she rejects the decision. None of that was known prior to this inquiry. "That is why one of the other recommendations is that the Senate agrees that when Mr Joyce arrives back in Australia, he will appear before this committee and give us the key evidence that has been hidden from us thus far, because the minister has gagged her department, as has the prime minister gagged his." Senator McKenzie said the Senate will vote next week to request Mr Joyce's attendance before the committee. "All the evidence received by this inquiry suggests there's only three people that know the real answer to this: the [transport] minster, the prime minister, and Mr Joyce ," she said. "If he won't agree to appear, we have the power to summons him, which the committee has already decided it will do because Mr Joyce, despite no longer being the CEO, was the figure, because of his close personal and political relationship with the prime minster, was the person that we believe intervened and influenced Minister King's change of mind between January and July. " Without his evidence, we won't be able to get to the bottom of it. " Mr Joyce is currently overseas, and it is not yet known when he will return to Australia.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Qantas CEO Alan Joyce 'will appear' at Qatar Airways inquiry

image.altText: Composite image of Lachie Schultz, Ben McKay and Xavier Duursma

items.synopsis: A free agency decision on Ben McKay could shape the AFL trade period, while Xavier Duursma and Lachie Schultz request moves to Victorian clubs. Get the latest news, analysis and discussion in our live blog.

title.children: AFL's bombshell McKay decision to shape trade period as Bombers close in on massive haul

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's official — Ben McKay is heading to Essendon, and the AFL is awarding North Melbourne pick three as compensation. SEN and AFL.com.au have reported the news and the AFL is expected to confirm it shortly. That gives North Melbourne picks 2, 3, 15, 21, 44, 56 and 64. Plus two extra late first round picks next year that the AFL has effectively encouraged them to trade this year. It's quite an incredible position to be in.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ben McKay compensation is officially pick three

children.content: (Getty Images)
It's official — Ben McKay is heading to Essendon, and the AFL is awarding North Melbourne pick three as compensation.
SEN and AFL.com.au have reported the news and the AFL is expected to confirm it shortly.
That gives North Melbourne picks 2, 3, 15, 21, 44, 56 and 64. Plus two extra late first round picks next year that the AFL has effectively encouraged them to trade this year.
It's quite an incredible position to be in.

items.synopsis: The falcons have been laying eggs on the top of the 34-storey building since 1991, but this year, there won't be hatchlings.

image.altText: Michael takes a selfie standing next to his wife

items.synopsis: After 15 years of infertility treatment, Michael Hughes and his wife were left childless and grieving. But since then, they have found healing.

title.children: 'I can't do this anymore': Your stories of being childless not by choice

image.altText: A young woman with short copper hair leaning on a fence post. She is wearing a black shirt

items.synopsis: After more than a year of gruelling treatments for melanoma, she is now raising awareness about the prevalence of the disease among young people.

title.children: At just 19, Crystal thought her itchy spot was harmless. Then she went for a skin check

image.altText: Three images cut together. Two dogs at the beach, one dog at a house.

items.synopsis: Clancy, Zar, Koda and Peggy lived in the same Geraldton area. Within a month, they all suffered sudden, agonising deaths.

title.children: 'The most horrific death': Four pet dogs die with similar symptoms in same suburb

image.altText: A man crouching down in Australian bush while light smoke from a small fire rises behind him

items.synopsis: More bush could have been treated despite the wet weather of the last few years, according to Firesticks Alliance co-founder Victor Steffensen.

title.children: As bushfires devastate communities, one leader says a key preparation tool has been under-utilised

image.altText: Two people sit in hot springs water surrounded by steam and sand

items.synopsis: The ABC can reveal a sacred women's site in the Northern Territory has been impacted by government infrastructure at a popular tourist hot spring.

title.children: Sacred site at popular NT hot springs impacted by government-constructed bore
